author: Astrid Zweynert
title: Britain pardons thousands of gay men for convictions under abolished laws
text:
Britain pardons thousands of gay men for convictions under abolished laws Astrid Zweynert twitter TWEET More 
London: Britain has pardoned thousands of gay and bisexual men convicted of crimes under sexual offence laws which have now been abolished. 
The so-called "Turing's Law" named after Alan Turing, the celebrated mathematician who was convicted of gross indecency in 1952 for having sex with a man, clears thousands of men of crimes of which they would be innocent today. SHARE Pin to Pinterest PIN Link A performer dressed as the Queen speaks with a police officer as hundreds of people take part in the annual LGBT York Pride parade in York, England, in June. Photo: Getty Images 
It follows on from the 2013 exoneration of the World War II code-breaker. 
Homosexual acts were not decriminalised in England until 1967 and it was not until 2001 that the age of consent for homosexuals was reduced to 16, making it the same as for heterosexuals. SHARE Pin to Pinterest PIN Link The portrait and notebook of British mathematician Alan Turing, who was stripped of his job and chemically castrated because he was gay. Photo: AP 
Under the new rules, gay and bisexual men convicted of consensual same-sex acts can be pardoned as long as it can be proved that the sexual act was consensual and the partner was over the age of consent. 
For those still alive, the offences will be removed from any criminal record checks via a "disregard process". Advertisement 
"This is a truly momentous day," Justice Minister Sam Gyimah said in a statement. "We can never undo the hurt caused, but we have apologised and taken action to right these wrongs." 
Turing, who cracked Nazi Germany's "unbreakable" Enigma code, was stripped of his job and chemically castrated after his 1952 conviction. He killed himself two years later, aged 41. SHARE
